			Fossils are helping Chapman University students find new passions		

Students at the university are helping uncover the bones of a 78-million-year-old dinosaurShare this:Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)Click to print (Opens in new window)

 
						As Paleontologist and Chapman University Presidential Fellow Jack Horner, center, and fellow student Greta Kunze look on, Ben Rotenberg, left, a senior at Chapman University, uses a dental tool to remove the casing and other material from around the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, at Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
		

By Destiny Torres | dtorres@scng.com | PUBLISHED: May 1, 2023 at 8:03 a.m. | UPDATED: May 1, 2023 at 8:05 a.m.When Chapman University screen acting student Ben Rotenberg learned his friends were heading to Montana to film a documentary about the students who helped excavate a set of 78-million-year-old dinosaur bones, he begged them to let him come along.
About a year later, not only is Rotenberg, a senior, helping to uncover those pelvic bones, but he also uncovered a passion for working with fossils.
Each summer, Jack Horner, paleontologist and presidential fellow at Chapman University, takes students to a ranch in Montana for hands-on experience digging up dinosaur bones.
The bones discovered by Chapman student Sarah Wallace last year were carefully excavated – along with the big chunk of dirt surrounding them – and wrapped in protective plaster to be brought back to the university for students to continue carefully digging free from the rock.
“I was brought to Chapman to work with students and try to get them to consider other ways to think,” said Horner, who has been a technical advisor on the “Jurassic Park” movies and was an inspiration behind the character Dr. Alan Grant depicted in the movies and the 1990 book. “Paleontology not being something that we have here at Chapman, offers the students experiences with the geological past that they wouldn’t normally get here.”
An illustration showing in red, the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, that were found in 2022 in northern Montana and brought back to Chapman University in Orange. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Using a dental tool, Ben Rotenberg, a senior at Chapman University, works on removing the casing and other material from around the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, at Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Greta Kunze, a freshman at Chapman University in Orange, talks about her work in the lab on the the pelvic bones of a Gryposaurus that were found in 2022 in northern Montana and brought back to Chapman University. An illustration of a Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago hangs on the wall behind her, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Using a dental tool, Ben Rotenberg, a senior at Chapman University, works on removing the casing and other material from around the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, at Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Paleontologist and Chapman University Presidential Fellow Jack Horner talks about his work of finding dinosaur bones in Montana and bringing the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago back to Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. Horner was the technical advisor for the Jurassic Park and Jurassic World movies. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Using a dental tool, Ben Rotenberg, a senior at Chapman University, works on removing the casing and other material from around the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, at Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
An illustration of a Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, hangs on the wall of the lab at Chapman University in Orange on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic bones of a Gryposaurus were found in 2022 in northern Montana and brought back to Chapman University. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
One of the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, that has been removed from the casing at Chapman University in Orange. Next to it sits a toy likeness of the Gryposaurus, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Holding a cast of a foot of a similar dinosaur to the bones they have in the lab, Paleontologist and Chapman University Presidential Fellow Jack Horner talks about his work of finding dinosaur bones in Montana and bringing the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago back to Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. Horner was the technical advisor for the Jurassic Park and Jurassic World movies. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
As Paleontologist and Chapman University Presidential Fellow Jack Horner, center, and fellow student Greta Kunze look on, Ben Rotenberg, left, a senior at Chapman University, uses a dental tool to remove the casing and other material from around the pelvic bones of a 30-foot-long Gryposaurus, a type of duck-billed dinosaur that lived about 78 million years ago, at Chapman University in Orange in 2022, on Wednesday, April 26, 2023. The pelvic fossil was found in 2022 in northern Montana. (Photo by Mark Rightmire, Orange County Register/SCNG)
Show Caption of Expand
Once removed from the rock, students will be able to make 3D models of the bones that can be further studied to learn about the species, what kinds of forces the pelvis could withstand and more. 


The pelvic bones are believed to be part of a Gryposaurus, a type of herbivorous, duck-billed dinosaur that walked the earth about 75 to 80 million years ago.
After graduating from Chapman with a degree in screen acting, Rotenberg will attend the University of Washington for his master’s degree in museum studies. But first, this summer, he’ll be back digging in Montana. 


“The University of Washington and specifically the (Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture) are actually the rightful owners of the fossils that I’m working on right now. They’ve left it to us and our crew for the preparation process,” Rotenberg said. “Eventually, all of the bones that are in my lab will eventually end up in their collection at the University of Washington, so it’s very exciting to be able to continue my education and follow this dinosaur along as it completes its journey.”
Rotenberg said he has been a huge dinosaur fan since he was a kid, so his family is not  surprised that he ultimately found his way into a dinosaur lab.
“We talk a lot about thinking outside of the box here at Chapman, so this is just kind of an opportunity for students to be able to do that,” he said, adding that the doors to their lab are always open for Chapman students or members of the community who want learn more about the process of uncovering fossils.

Destiny Torres

| Reporter


						Destiny Torres covers the local county government for the Orange County Register. She previously worked at the Los Angeles Business Journal where she covered L.A.'s growing tech industry. She started her journalistic journey at CSU Dominguez Hills where she was an editor for the university's student-run newspaper The Bulletin. In 2022, she earned her master's degree in journalism from the University of Southern California. More of Destiny's words can be found at Remezcla, LA School Report and the Los Angeles Times Español. When she isn't on deadline, Destiny can usually be found baking, reading or watching 50 First Dates for the millionth time.
